author: By Rory Smith
title: The Contenders
description: As the Women’s World Cup has expanded, so, too, has the group of nations with the firm belief that they can win it.
content: The Women’s World Cup, which opens this week, is the biggest in its 32-year history, but it may also be the most open field the tournament has seen.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeanna Smialek
title: Jerome Powell’s Prized Labor Market Is Back. Can He Keep It?
description: The Federal Reserve chair spent the early pandemic bemoaning the loss of a strong job market. It roared back — and now its fate is in his hands.
content: Jerome H. Powell, the chair of the Federal Reserve, spent the early pandemic lamenting something America had lost: a job market so historically strong that it was boosting marginalized groups, extending opportunities to people and communities that had long lived without them.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin and Katie Robertson
title: John Harris Named Top Editor at Politico
description: Mr. Harris, who helped found the media outlet in 2007, will succeed Matt Kaminski as the publication’s editor in the United States, with additional oversight of international editions.
content: Politico said Monday that its top U.S. editor was stepping down and would be replaced by one of the publication’s co-founders, John Harris, who will also take on additional responsibilities for the media outlet’s international editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Madison Malone Kircher
title: How PinkyDoll Mesmerized the Internet
description: Her TikTok catchphrase, “Ice cream so good,” has become a meme.
content: If you watch a livestream video hosted by the TikTok creator PinkyDoll, it won’t be long before you hear her say, “Ice cream so good.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ben Sisario
title: Taylor Swift Now Has More No. 1 Albums Than Any Woman in History
description: The pop superstar’s “Speak Now (Taylor’s Version)” debuts at No. 1 this week as the year’s biggest new album, and three of her other titles also made the Top 10.
content: When Taylor Swift released “Speak Now (Taylor’s Version)” this month, there was no doubt it would debut at No. 1. The only questions were how forcefully it would smash records, how many mountains of vinyl it would sell and how far down the chart Swift’s catalog would push everybody else.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By John Branch and Adam Stoltman
title: A Long, Shining River of Verse, Flowing From a Rower and Writer
description: Spend a day on the water with Wang Ping and you will discover a source of her poetry.
content: The heart beats alone, keeping its own pace
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dwight Garner
title: After a Great Flood, a Struggle Between Faith and Reason
description: Khaled Khalifa’s new novel follows two friends through disaster and religious tension in early-20th-century Syria.
content: The Syrian writer Khaled Khalifa’s novels have cruel titles, of the sort Jean Genet might have composed for William S. Burroughs, or Verlaine for Rimbaud.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Do Legacy Admissions Also Benefit the Less Elite?
description: Readers discuss a guest essay by a Princeton professor. Also: Republicans and the military bill; Russian land mines; reducing child drowning deaths.
content: To the Editor:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chelsia Rose Marcius
title: At N.Y.C. Police Union, Will the New Leader Be a Lot Like the Old One?
description: Patrick Hendry, a reserved, behind-the-scenes power, is succeeding the fiery Patrick Lynch, who ran the Police Benevolent Association at top volume.
content: Patrick Hendry, the new head of New York City’s police officers’ union, has much in common with his predecessor: Their mothers are from Ireland. They grew up in Queens, the sons of union men. And they believe a police union must defend officers, even those accused of wrongdoing.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Loudin
title: It’s Marathon Training Season. Here’s How to Build a Foundation.
description: The first few weeks should focus on the basics — easy pace, weight training and setting your expectations.
content: Every year, more than a million people around the world run a marathon. For some, it will be one of many, but for others, it will be a highlight of their lives. If you’re drawn to the challenge and excitement of running a “26.2” this year (or sometime in the future), you’ve got work to do. And we’re here to help.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Why Every Women’s World Cup City Has Two Names
description: A concerted effort to say Indigenous names correctly, and tell the stories behind them, will show up in stadiums in New Zealand and Australia.
content: When soccer fans land in New Zealand this month ahead of the Women’s World Cup, they may find themselves welcomed not to Auckland or Wellington, but to “Tāmaki Makaurau” (“Tah-mah-key Ma-kow-row”) or “Te Whanganui-a-Tara” (“Tay Fung-a-noo-ee a Tah-rah”).
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer and Karen Zraick
title: Edward Caban Becomes First Latino Police Commissioner in New York
description: Mayor Eric Adams named Mr. Caban as the 46th commissioner of the New York Police Department. He follows Keechant Sewell, who resigned after 18 months.
content: Edward Caban, who grew up in the Bronx as the son of a Puerto Rican transit police detective, on Monday became the first Latino officer to lead the New York Police Department in its 177-year history.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elie Levine
title: Today’s Wordle Review
description: Our columnist reviews the day’s puzzle. Warning: Contains spoilers!
content: Welcome to The Wordle Review. Be warned: This article contains spoilers for today’s puzzle. Solve Wordle first, or scroll at your own risk.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Austin Considine
title: Tim Baltz on How B.J. Grabbed a Win in ‘The Righteous Gemstones’
description: Sunday’s episode was a test for Baltz’s character, but B.J. seized the moment. Still, his victory came at a price.
content: This interview contains spoilers for Sunday night’s episode of “The Righteous Gemstones.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Frank Rojas and Brian Fraser
title: Celebrating Their Roots at Curlfest
description: The natural hair and beauty festival returned after three years away.
content: On a hot and humid Saturday in New York, attendees did their best to keep cool for Curlfest, an outdoor event on Randall’s Island celebrating Black hair. Local vendors in a grassy field awaited a sea of festivalgoers showing off their most elaborate and personal box braids, cornrows, Afros and twists. From his station on the stage, a D.J. played the 2004 Jill Scott song “Golden.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By David Leonhardt
title: A Positive Covid Milestone
description: In a sign that the pandemic really is over, the total number of Americans dying each day is no longer historically abnormal.
content: The United States has reached a milestone in the long struggle against Covid: The total number of Americans dying each day — from any cause — is no longer historically abnormal.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Josh Ocampo
title: Is the Future of Twitter Hanging by Threads?
description: Ryan Mac, a New York Times technology reporter, discussed Twitter’s latest competitor and what it was like to be blocked from the platform he covered.
content: Ryan Mac, a technology reporter who covers Twitter for The New York Times, is used to changing his plans at a moment’s notice.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Ana Swanson
title: House Committee Targets U.C. Berkeley Program for China Ties
description: A House select committee is requesting more information about a university collaboration that it said could help China gain access to cutting-edge research.
content: A congressional committee focused on national security threats from China said it had “grave concerns” about a research partnership between the University of California, Berkeley, and several Chinese entities, claiming that the collaboration’s advanced research could help the Chinese government gain an economic, technological or military advantage.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: China’s Rebound Falters, Tripped Up by Debt and Weak Exports
description: Government data shows gross domestic product growth slowed in the second quarter from earlier in the year, even though it rose over the same period in 2022.
content: China’s economy slowed markedly in the spring from earlier in the year, official numbers released on Monday showed, as exports tumbled, a real estate slump deepened and some debt-ridden local governments had to cut spending after running low on money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Emily St. James
title: I Am Being Pushed Out of One of the Last Public Squares, the Library
description: A haven that should welcome all is too often becoming a battleground.
content: As far as my childhood self was concerned, the Carnegie Library in my tiny South Dakota hometown was the best place on earth. Once every week, I climbed its stairs and entered a space that smelled of mildew and oak.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Styles Desk
title: This Barbie Is Now on Strike
description: The actors’ strike effectively ended the “Barbie” film’s press tour. But Margot Robbie’s pink-carpet outfits are worth remembering.
content: The actors’ strike has hit the brakes on the hot pink convertible that is the “Barbie” film’s press tour.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Constant Méheut
title: Wildfire Forces Thousands to Evacuate in Canary Islands
description: The blaze on the island of La Palma has driven some 4,000 residents from their homes and burned about 10,000 acres. Wildfires also broke out in Greece.
content: Spanish firefighters on Monday were battling a wildfire that has raged for three days on the wooded slopes of La Palma in the Canary Islands, forcing the evacuation of more than 4,000 residents.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Catherine Porter and Constant Méheut
title: Riots in France Highlight a Vicious Cycle Between Police and Minorities
description: Calls to overhaul the police go back decades. But violent episodes of police enforcement continue. So do violent outpourings on the street.
content: Years before France was inflamed with anger at the police killing of a teenager during a traffic stop, there was the notorious Théo Luhaka case.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Elena Bergeron
title: Saquon Barkley and Giants Cannot Agree to Long-Term Deal
description: The team and Barkley, a two-time Pro Bowl running back, missed an N.F.L. deadline Monday with training camp just over a week away.
content: The Giants failed to reach a long-term contract with Saquon Barkley, their star running back, by the N.F.L. deadline on Monday, leaving the two sides at a stalemate over whether he will play this season.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sopan Deb
title: Playwrights’ Hoop Dreams Take Flight Off Broadway This Summer
description: Basketball is central to the plot in new shows, including “Flex” and “The Half-God of Rainfall.”
content: In Inua Ellams’s new play, “The Half-God of Rainfall,” the gods play thunderous games of basketball in the heavens. For Candrice Jones’s “Flex,” high schoolers practice their defensive stances while scraping by in rural Arkansas. Near the end of Rajiv Joseph’s “King James,” the two main characters play a one-on-one game of basketball using a crumpled up piece of paper after waxing poetic about the greatness of the N.B.A. star LeBron James.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Zachary Small
title: City Approves Design for Shirley Chisholm Monument in Prospect Park
description: It took officials more than four years to say yes to the towering lattice steel statue by Amanda Williams and Olalekan B. Jeyifous.
content: On Monday, city officials approved designs for a monument to Shirley Chisholm, who, in 1968, was elected the first Black woman to serve in Congress, representing a district that encompassed her childhood neighborhood of Bedford-Stuyvesant. A national symbol of empowerment for women and people of color, Chisholm was also the first woman to seek the Democratic presidential nomination.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Astor
title: Robert F. Kennedy Jr.’s Relatives Condemn His Bigoted Comments on Covid
description: His sister Kerry Kennedy criticized his remarks, and his brother Joseph Kennedy II said “they play on antisemitic myths and stoke mistrust of the Chinese.”
content: Several members of the Kennedy family have condemned a bigoted conspiracy theory from the Democratic presidential candidate Robert F. Kennedy Jr., who suggested that the coronavirus was “ethnically targeted” to spare Jews and Chinese people.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Brandon Yu
title: ‘Unknown: Cave of Bones’ Review: Making Us Human
description: This Netflix documentary chronicles archaeological discoveries that shed light on an ancient human relative.
content: “It challenges us to question: What does it even mean to be human?” This declaration comes from Agustín Fuentes, an anthropologist, at the beginning of “Unknown: Cave of Bones,” and it becomes a refrain throughout this documentary. It’s the kind of statement that can read as trite and grandiose — particularly in the context of a science program — but here it has a gravity that is reinforced and viscerally felt over the course of the film.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jonathan Swan, Charlie Savage and Maggie Haberman
title: Trump and Allies Forge Plans to Increase Presidential Power in 2025
description: The former president and his backers aim to strengthen the power of the White House and limit the independence of federal agencies.
content: Donald J. Trump and his allies are planning a sweeping expansion of presidential power over the machinery of government if voters return him to the White House in 2025, reshaping the structure of the executive branch to concentrate far greater authority directly in his hands.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By William K. Rashbaum and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Former N.Y.C. Buildings Chief Expected to Face Bribery-Related Charges
description: Eric Ulrich, who was the commissioner of New York City’s Buildings Department, resigned in November amid an investigation by the Manhattan district attorney’s office.
content: A criminal investigation into the former commissioner of New York City’s Buildings Department has reached its final stages and charges are expected as soon as this week, according to three people with knowledge of the inquiry.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: Honoring the Last of the ‘Boys of Summer’
description: Carl Erskine was a champion with the 1955 Brooklyn Dodgers, but what came after that is what will be celebrated with an award from the Baseball Hall of Fame.
content: It is the first inning, you might say, and Carl Erskine does not have his best stuff. A camera crew has set up in his living room, and a filmmaker, Ted Green, gently tries to guide Erskine through a short speech. This is hard work for the old Brooklyn Dodger, who needs several takes.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Kai Bird
title: The Tragedy of J. Robert Oppenheimer
description: Christopher Nolan’s film delves deeply into what this country did to its most famous scientist.
content: One day in the spring of 1954, J. Robert Oppenheimer ran into Albert Einstein outside their offices at the Institute for Advanced Study in Princeton, N.J. Oppenheimer had been the director of the institute since 1947 and Einstein a faculty member since he fled Germany in 1933. The two men might argue about quantum physics — Einstein grumbled that he just didn’t think that God played dice with the universe — but they were good friends.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maggie Haberman
title: Ramaswamy Looks to Supreme Court in Effort to Appeal to Conservatives
description: The long-shot Republican presidential candidate is releasing a list of potential justices to highlight his bona fides with key voters.
content: Vivek Ramaswamy, an entrepreneur running for the Republican presidential nomination, on Monday released a list of potential choices for the U.S. Supreme Court, in an effort to highlight his conservative credentials to early-state voters who may be skeptical of a candidate without a political background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Miguel Salazar
title: The Dark Magic Wrought by a Nazi Occultist and a Doomed Horror Film
description: Silvia Moreno-Garcia’s new novel, “Silver Nitrate,” is about friends whose attempt to lift an old curse unleashes something even more terrifying.
content: Silvia Moreno-Garcia’s dexterity with genre — oscillating between horror, thriller, crime and gothic — is well known by now, as is her penchant for mashing them with historical Mexican settings. Her stories have ranged from a quest narrative and romance in an alternate 1920s Mexico to a reimagining of H.G. Wells’s “The Island of Doctor Moreau” in the 18th-century Yucatán Peninsula.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Veronique Greenwood
title: What Benjamin Franklin Learned While Fighting Counterfeiters
description: Long before there were Benjamins in circulation, the founding father was all about experimenting with printing techniques as he worked on securing colonial printed currency.
content: When Benjamin Franklin moved to Philadelphia in 1723, he got to witness the beginning of a risky new experiment: Pennsylvania had just begun printing words on paper and calling it money.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: A Pro-Trump Crowd, Sensing Disloyalty, Drowns Out Dissent
description: A day after former President Donald J. Trump headlined the Turning Point conference in Florida, two of his Republican opponents were booed and heckled at the same event.
content: Not long ago, the names on the marquee would have been right at home on Fox News: Stephen K. Bannon, Tucker Carlson and Roger J. Stone Jr.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soumya Karlamangla
title: Millions of Californians Are Expected to Lose Medi-Cal Coverage
description: As the state verifies eligibility for its Medicaid program after a pandemic pause, up to 2.8 million Californians could be kicked off the rolls, officials say.
content: A big change is underway for one of California’s most popular safety net programs.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Lisa Friedman
title: Kerry Says U.S. and China Must Set Aside Politics to Tackle Climate Change
description: John Kerry, President Biden’s climate envoy, is in Beijing for three days of talks between the world’s largest emitters of greenhouse gas pollution.
content: The United States and China are running out of time to avert a harrowing future brought on by global warming, John Kerry, President Biden’s envoy for climate change, warned on Monday at the resumption of talks with Beijing that had stalled for nearly a year amid geopolitical tensions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Tyler Kepner
title: How Do You Pitch to Stan Musial? Very Carefully.
description: Carl Erskine is one of the last stars left from a golden age of baseball. He offered insights into what it was like to face some of the greats, and how the game has changed.
content: In 1954, when The Sporting News polled writers about the players they covered, Carl Erskine stood out. Among his fellow Brooklyn Dodgers, Erskine was cited for several attributes, including “Best Marriage,” “Best Parent,” “Most Intellectual” and “Best Conversationalist.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Carl Hulse
title: Democrats to Press Supreme Court Ethics Rules Over G.O.P. Opposition
description: The Senate Judiciary Committee is slated to approve new disclosure requirements, although the legislation is unlikely to advance.
content: Senate Democrats plan to push ahead this week with legislation imposing new ethics rules on the Supreme Court in the wake of disclosures about the justices’ travel and outside activities, despite blanket opposition by Republicans who claim the effort is intended to undermine the high court.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Asher Elbein and Nina Riggio
title: A Fossil Dream as Big as Texas
description: Andre LuJan’s ambition is to build a public museum focused on displaying the Lone Star State’s paleontological plenty.
content: Most people come to Ox Ranch — an 18,000-acre property outside Uvalde, Texas — for the thrill of hunting exotic animals in the Hill Country. But the ranch is also home to ancient secrets, as in lines of dinosaur tracks that cut across an empty creek bed and in a dark cave under a stony hillside that contains the remnants of Pleistocene animals and humans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Danny Hakim
title: Georgia Supreme Court Rejects Trump Effort to Quash Investigation
description: With indictment decisions imminent, the court refused to scuttle an investigation into whether the former president and his allies interfered in the 2020 election.
content: ATLANTA — In a ruling on Monday, the Georgia Supreme Court rejected a long-shot attempt by former President Donald J. Trump’s legal team to scuttle an investigation into election interference weeks before indictment decisions are expected.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Camille Baker
title: Consejos para iniciarte en el avistamiento de aves
description: Alli Smith, del Laboratorio de Ornitología de la Universidad Cornell, ofrece consejos para que los principiantes comiencen a explorar el vasto mundo de las aves.
content: Este verano, como parte del proyecto de avistamiento de aves de The New York Times, el Times compartirá una serie de indicaciones para ayudar a los lectores a iniciarse en la observación de aves. Comencemos con una habilidad fundamental: aprender a identificar algunas de las aves que es más común observar cerca del área en que resides.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Fahy
title: Aliyah Boston Has Officially Arrived
description: Boston, the Indiana Fever rookie forward and center, has already become a face of the W.N.B.A. just months into her professional career.
content: Aliyah Boston said she usually keeps it cool when she faces the star basketball players she grew up watching on television. But her poker face slipped last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Deb Amlen
title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: Entries for the week of July 10, 2023.
content: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes. It is probably also worth mentioning that the Diary is a work of fiction.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chris Buckley and David Pierson
title: Where Is China’s Foreign Minister? Beijing Won’t Clear Up the Mystery.
description: Qin Gang has not made a public appearance in three weeks. The Communist Party’s habitual secrecy around top officials has fueled speculation over the reasons for his absence.
content: After China’s leader, Xi Jinping, catapulted Qin Gang into the post of foreign minister in December, Mr. Qin set a frantic pace, meeting dozens of foreign officials as he pressed Beijing’s agenda in a divided, war-stricken world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Ravi Mattu, Bernhard Warner, Sarah Kessler, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: China’s Economy Is Sputtering, Posing a Challenge for Global Growth
description: New data published on Monday shows a post-pandemic recovery has not materialized after restrictions were lifted last year.
content: When China finally lifted Covid restrictions last year, policymakers and companies hoped that it would help lift the global economy out of its post-pandemic doldrums. But data released on Monday shows that the hoped-for recovery in the world’s second-biggest economy still hasn’t materialized, raising wider questions about global growth, the implications for international business and China’s dealings with the outside world.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Monika Pronczuk
title: In a Bid to Curb Migrants, Europe Strikes a Deal With Tunisia
description: After the deadliest shipwreck in years in the Mediterranean, E.U. officials will pay Tunisia to prevent migrants from setting to sea.
content: BRUSSELS — The European Union has struck a deal with Tunisia to try to stem the number of migrants crossing the Mediterranean, amid heated debate over the fallout of the bloc’s migration policies, including a shipwreck last month that was the deadliest in years.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Chang Che
title: More Than 50 Whales Die After Being Stranded in Scotland
description: Only one pilot whale survived out of the 55 beached on the Isle of Lewis in northwest Scotland on Sunday. It was the largest mass stranding in the region in over a decade.
content: More than 50 pilot whales died on Sunday after they were stranded along a beach on the Isle of Lewis in northwest Scotland. It was the largest mass stranding event in Britain since 2011, marine rescuers say.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Paul Krugman
title: Why We Should Politicize the Weather
description: Climate-related disasters are very much a partisan issue.
content: After officially beginning his presidential campaign, Ron DeSantis was asked about climate change. He brushed the issue aside: “I’ve always rejected the politicization of the weather.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Peter Coy
title: This Statistic Could Be Distorting How We Think About Inflation
description: A newly minted economist makes a case that giants in his field are looking at the data wrong.
content: Preston Mui earned his doctorate in economics from the University of California, Berkeley, just last year, but he’s already making waves. This month he called out some of the biggest names in economics and policymaking in a blog post.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Natasha Frost
title: Your Monday Briefing
description: Britain’s troubled health service.
content: Britain’s National Health Service turns 75 this month. It is in the deepest crisis of its history: flooded by aging patients; starved of investment; and understaffed by doctors and nurses, many of whom are so burned out that they are either joining strikes or leaving for jobs abroad.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert Ito
title: What Does It Mean to be Blind? A Writer Chronicles the Loss of His Vision.
description: In “The Country of the Blind,” Andrew Leland explores the history, the culture and the experiences of blind people.
content: In 2019, Andrew Leland began writing a book about blindness, even as he was going steadily blind himself.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Santora, Neil MacFarquhar and Haley Willis
title: Explosions Damage Crimea Bridge as Russia Blames Ukraine for Attack
description: Russia accused Ukraine of hitting the Kerch Strait Bridge for the second time in 10 months, saying that two maritime drones had struck the bridge, an essential supply line for Russian troops.
content: Predawn explosions hit the only bridge linking the occupied Crimean Peninsula to mainland Russia on Monday, damaging a vital symbol of President Vladimir V. Putin’s claims to sovereignty over Ukrainian territory and briefly disrupting a major supply line to Russian troops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Soo Youn
title: Less Cocaine, More Vegetables: Concert Tour Cooking Goes Healthy
description: Today’s artists, like Beyoncé, Paul McCartney and Lizzo, travel with an elaborate entourage of culinary professionals making increasingly mindful meals.
content: In Stockholm, it was the cookies — the black sesame, wasabi and white chocolate, or maybe the gluten-free coconut almond dark chocolate — that signaled to Beyoncé’s dancers, crew and roadies that Grant Bird was back.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jeffrey Gettleman and Finbarr O'Reilly
title: Far From the Front, They Stand in Honor of Ukraine
description: The city of Chernivtsi in western Ukraine has been spared the mayhem of the Russian invasion. But like other towns in the region, it is doing its part, and has become, in effect, a back office of the war effort.
content: Every morning at the stroke of 9, in the western Ukrainian city of Chernivtsi, the entire town square comes to a standstill for a moment of silence to mourn the war dead.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Bogel-Burroughs
title: Family of Murdaugh Boat Crash Victim Reaches $15 Million Settlement
description: The crash, in which a 19-year-old woman was killed, brought scrutiny to Alex Murdaugh and his family. He was later convicted of murdering his wife and son.
content: When jurors reached a verdict this year in the trial of Alex Murdaugh, a fourth-generation South Carolina lawyer, they found him guilty of murdering his wife and younger son. But looming large over the trial was another tragic death: that of Mallory Beach, a 19-year-old woman who was killed in a boat crash involving the dead son years earlier.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Vivian Yee and Leily Nikounazar
title: Iran Steps Up Policing of Women Who Defy Strict Dress Code
description: The country’s morality police disappeared from the streets late last year as the authorities tried to calm anti-government protests. Now, patrols are once again watching for violators.
content: Iran is once again deploying police officers on the streets to enforce its conservative dress code for women, which many have flouted since the protest movement that rattled the country began last fall, according to state news media and social media posts.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Pam Belluck
title: Treating Alzheimer’s Very Early Offers Better Hope of Slowing Decline, Study Finds
description: A trial of donanemab, an experimental drug, found it modestly slowed the worsening of memory and thinking and worked better in patients at earlier stages and those under 75.
content: Treating Alzheimer’s patients as early as possible — when symptoms and brain pathology are mildest — provides a better chance of slowing cognitive decline, a large study of an experimental Alzheimer’s drug presented Monday suggests.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Barron
title: After Arrest in Serial Killings, a Profile Looks Prescient
description: In several ways, Rex Heuermann, the suspect in the Gilgo Beach killings, fits a profile that criminologists assembled more than a decade ago.
content: Good morning. It’s Monday. We’ll look at the suspect in the Gilgo Beach killings who was arrested last week.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jazmine Ulloa
title: DeSantis, Haley and Pence Attack Democrats in Speeches Supporting Israel
description: President Biden and progressive congresswomen were the focus of Republican presidential hopefuls’ criticism at the Christians United for Israel Summit.
content: Gov. Ron DeSantis of Florida on Monday sharply criticized the Biden administration’s policies on Israel, calling them “disgraceful,” seeking to highlight his pro-Israel credentials as he goes head-to-head with former President Donald J. Trump for evangelical voters.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Caity Weaver
title: My Impossible Mission to Find Tom Cruise
description: The action star has gone to great lengths to avoid the press for more than a decade. But maybe our writer could track him down anyway?
content: In an interview with Playboy in 2012, Tom Cruise described Katie Holmes as “an extraordinary person” with a “wonderful” clothing line, and someone for whom he was fond of “doing things like creating romantic dinners” — behavior that, he confided, “she enjoys.” It would prove to be his last major interview with a reporter to date. Despite what may be recalled through the penumbra of memory, this sudden silence was not directly preceded by either of Cruise’s infamous appearances on television: not by his NBC’s “Today” show interview (in which he labeled host Matt Lauer both “glib” and “Matt — MattMattMattMatt”), nor even by his appearance on “The Oprah Winfrey Show” (in which he reverse-catapulted himself onto Winfrey’s fawn-colored couch multiple times in a demonstration of his enthusiasm for Holmes). Those incidents occurred seven years earlier, in 2005; Cruise emerged from the hex of public bewilderment unscathed. In fact, Cruise gave no indication that the interview, pegged to the musical-comedy bomb “Rock of Ages,” was intended to serve as a farewell address to journalists. At the time he sat for it, another life milestone was hurtling toward him: The month after the article was published, Holmes filed for divorce.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robert D. McFadden
title: Beverly Moss Spatt, Protector of Landmarks in New York, Dies at 99
description: Grand Central Terminal. Grand Army Plaza. The Queensboro Bridge. They, and more, were preserved as historic treasures under her fierce watch at the city’s landmarks commission.
content: Beverly Moss Spatt, a fierce defender of New York City’s aesthetic and cultural heritage who battled real estate and political interests to protect distinguished buildings and historic districts as chairwoman of the city’s Landmarks Preservation Commission in the 1970s, died on Friday in Brooklyn. She was 99.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sal Cataldi
title: The Jazzy Tune You Heard on Hold? This Part-Time Musician Made It.
description: Meet Harriet Goldberg, a late bloomer who went from a career in social work to the queen of hold music with her 2011 song “My Time to Fly.”
content: Harriet Goldberg is the composer of what may be one of the most heard songs in the world today.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Graham Bowley and Tom Mashberg
title: At the Met, She Holds Court. At Home, She Held 71 Looted Antiquities.
description: Shelby White has given the museum generous gifts and 33 years of service as a trustee. But investigators recently seized many of her ancient artifacts, including 17 that were on loan to the Met.
content: The exhibition was a major one, featuring nearly 200 ancient artifacts from around the world, including Neolithic marbles and imposing Roman bronzes, and its title, “Glories of the Past,” was appropriately grand.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Marc Tracy
title: For ‘Oppenheimer,’ These Fans Go to Great Lengths for Just 30 Screens
description: The IMAX 70-millimeter format is usually associated with action. But Christopher Nolan says his biopic benefited from the tall image.
content: On Friday morning, Vasili Birlidis and three friends will pile into a rented car in Gainesville, Fla., and drive 10 hours round-trip to see a movie that will be playing on thousands of screens across the country, including in their own town.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Jesus Jiménez
title: Deaths of 4 Women in Oregon Are Linked, Police Say
description: Law enforcement agencies have identified at least one person of interest in the deaths of the women, whose bodies were found in the northwestern part of the state from February to May.
content: The bodies of two women were discovered in wooded areas outside Portland, Ore. The body of another woman was found in a culvert. Another was spotted next to a creek.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By D.W. Gibson
title: She Opened a Bookshop in Brooklyn, Then Moved In Above the Store
description: A woman walking in Williamsburg saw an empty storefront for rent. It turned into a dream fulfilled. Upstairs, an apartment was being renovated.
content: For Simona Blat, the plan was to move to Europe and open a bookshop. It was early 2021, a global pandemic was still raging, and Williamsburg, her Brooklyn neighborhood of 12 years, felt like it was emptying out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Ivan Nechepurenko and Neil MacFarquhar
title: Russia pulls out of the Black Sea grain deal.
description: The Kremlin terminated an agreement that had allowed Ukraine to export its grain by sea despite a wartime blockade, a deal seen as essential to keeping global food prices stable.
content: Russia said on Monday that it was ending its participation in an agreement that had allowed Ukraine to export its grain by sea despite Moscow’s naval blockade, upending a deal that had helped to keep global food prices stable and alleviate one element of the global fallout from the war.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christina Jewett
title: F.D.A. Approves R.S.V. Shot for Infants
description: The respiratory virus is a global killer of babies and young children.
content: The Food and Drug Administration on Monday approved a shot to protect infants and vulnerable toddlers against respiratory syncytial virus, or R.S.V., offering one of the first protections for an illness that fills children’s hospitals year after year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Goldberg
title: The Hysterical Overreaction to Jayapal’s ‘Racist State’ Gaffe
description: A congresswoman runs into pro-Israel political correctness.
content: Last weekend, Representative Pramila Jayapal, a Washington Democrat who is chair of the Congressional Progressive Caucus, made a significant political error. She called Israel a “racist state,” instead of simply a state that has racist leaders who treat many of the people under their authority as second-class citizens or worse on account of their ethnic and religious background.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Sabrina Tavernise, Shannon Lin, Rachelle Bonja, Eric Krupke, M.J. Davis Lin, Marc Georges, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano, Chris Wood and Alyssa Moxley
title: China’s Economic Rebound Hits a Wall
description: When the country ended its lockdowns, business was expected to come roaring back. Here’s why it didn’t.
content: When China suddenly dismantled its lockdowns and other Covid precautions last December, officials in Beijing and many investors expected the economy to spring back to life. It hasn’t worked out that way.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Shivani Gonzalez
title: What’s on TV This Week: ‘Below Deck’ and FIFA Women’s World Cup
description: One “Below Deck” spinoff wraps up its season, as another begins on Bravo. And Fox begins coverage of the women’s soccer championship.
content: Between network, cable and streaming, the modern television landscape is a vast one. Here are some of the shows, specials and movies coming to TV this week, July 17-23. Details and times are subject to change.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Alex Marshall
title: Elton John Testifies at Kevin Spacey’s Sexual Assault Trial
description: The British singer and his husband, David Furnish, appeared via video link to give evidence for the defense in the actor’s ongoing British trial.
content: Elton John and his husband, David Furnish, appeared on Monday as defense witnesses in the British trial of the actor Kevin Spacey, who is accused of multiple counts of sexual assault.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Samuel G. Freedman
title: What We Can Learn From the Young Democratic Mayor Who Sent a Wing of His Own Party Into Exile
description: Hubert Humphrey’s 1948 triumph resonates today.
content: On the torrid afternoon of July 6, 1948, Hubert Humphrey departed one kind of inferno to plunge into another. The brash young mayor of Minneapolis was leaving a city reeling under a 100-degree heat wave that had taken two lives that very day. He was bound for Philadelphia, site of the impending Democratic National Convention, where the sweltering weather provided the fitting backdrop to a heated convention.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Claire Moses and Johnny Diaz
title: In Phoenix, 18 Days of 110-Degree Weather, and Counting
description: Tens of millions of people face dangerous levels of heat as record-breaking temperatures are expected this week from Texas to the lower Mississippi Valley, forecasters said.
content: A relentless heat wave that has sent temperatures into the triple digits brought Phoenix its 18th consecutive day of high temperatures at or above 110 degrees on Monday, tying a record set in 1974, officials said.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christoph Koettl and Christiaan Triebert
title: A large Wagner convoy arrives at a camp in Belarus.
description: The troop movements are the private company’s biggest — and most public — showing since its failed rebellion in Russia last month.
content: A large convoy of vehicles carrying Wagner mercenary troops arrived at a military field camp in Belarus on Monday morning, in what is the private company’s biggest — and most public — showing since its failed rebellion in Russia last month.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Ryerson
title: Harry G. Frankfurt, Philosopher With a Surprise Best Seller, Dies at 94
description: He spent his career exploring will and deceit. Then came a sudden success: a bluntly titled book that found that one strain of dishonesty with a barnyard name was worse than lying.
content: Harry G. Frankfurt, a philosopher whose fresh ideas about the human will were overshadowed in the broader culture by his analysis of a kind of dishonesty that he found worse than lying — an analysis presented in a bluntly titled surprise best seller, “On Bullshit” — died on Sunday in Santa Monica, Calif. He was 94.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Games
title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.
content: MONDAY — Hi busy bees! Welcome to today’s Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlen’s weekly humor column, “Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Seth Sherwood
title: Paris Is Packed in the Summer. Here Are Six Ways to Dodge the Droves.
description: European hot spots are buckling with record numbers of travelers this season. But even in a global travel darling like the French capital, strategies exist to enjoy the sights without the crowds.
content: Summer has arrived in Paris, and the world with it. By day, international hordes pile into the Musée d’Orsay to catch the final month of the blockbuster “Manet / Degas” exhibition as throngs surround the closed, fire-damaged Notre Dame Cathedral to snap any possible selfies. By night, the available picnic space quickly disappears on the lawns of the Champ de Mars and its direct view of the Eiffel Tower.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Maria Cramer
title: The Gilgo Beach Serial-Killing Case: What We Know
description: A Long Island architect has been charged with killing three women. The victims were among 10 people whose remains were found along a stretch of beach on Long Island.
content: In December 2010, Officer John Malia and his police dog, Blue, were combing Gilgo Beach, a remote stretch of sand on the South Shore of Long Island, when they found human remains.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christopher Kuo
title: In ‘Secret Invasion,’ Ben Mendelsohn Faces a Turning Point
description: In an interview, the Australian actor discusses his character’s big moment in the most recent episode and his role as ally to Samuel L. Jackson’s Nick Fury.
content: This article includes spoilers for the fourth episode of “Secret Invasion.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By James Wagner
title: Lionel Messi Gives M.L.S. First Taste of the Weight of His Star
description: One day after Messi’s contract with Inter Miami became official, the club presented him to fans in a rain-soaked stadium and on the league’s streaming platform.
content: Just before 9 p.m. on Sunday, the greatest soccer player of his era, and maybe the greatest of all time, walked across a makeshift stage in his new home stadium. He hugged the owners of his new team, including the former star David Beckham. As he held his new jersey — a pink No. 10 — Lionel Messi grinned and looked up at the crowd and the fireworks.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Keith Bradsher
title: One Reason China Is Willing to Engage Again: Its Troubled Economy
description: China was on track to recover after closing itself off during the pandemic. Now the country’s growth is staggering, and Beijing is signaling it is open to talking.
content: Three months ago it appeared that China’s economy was on track to recover relatively quickly after being closed off to the world during the pandemic. Consumers were spending again. Exports picked up. Even China’s beleaguered housing market gave hints it was stabilizing.
source.name: The New York Times

title: No Corrections: July 17, 2023
description: No corrections appeared in print on Monday, July 17, 2023.
content: Errors are corrected during the press run whenever possible, so some errors noted here may not have appeared in all editions.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Nicholas Fandos
title: House Democrats Prepare Push to Censure George Santos
description: The move will face long odds of passing the Republican-led House, but Democrats believe it will place pressure on G.O.P. leaders who recently censured Representative Adam Schiff.
content: House Democrats unveiled a resolution on Monday to formally censure Representative George Santos of New York for blatantly lying to voters about his life story, teeing up a fresh attempt to reprimand the freshman Republican.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Blinken Calls Blockade of Diplomatic Nominees a National Security Risk
description: The secretary of state’s plea came as Republicans, in a practice once considered beyond the pale, were stalling a wide range of President Biden’s nominees.
content: Secretary of State Antony J. Blinken called on the Senate to quickly confirm more than three dozen State Department nominees, charging that delaying tactics employed by Republican senators seeking leverage on unrelated issues were “undermining national security.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Christine Hauser and Claire Moses
title: Smoke Pollution From Canadian Wildfires Blankets U.S. Cities, Again
description: Wildfires in western Canada are expected to create smoky conditions in the United States this week. Parts of the U.S. had unhealthy air in June from wildfires in other parts of Canada.
content: Smoke from wildfires in Western Canada drifted across the Midwest and the Northeast of the United States on Monday, blotting out blue sky and sun and blanketing dozens of cities with unhealthy air that triggered warnings to limit the time spent outdoors.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By New York Times Audio
title: Today’s Top News: A New Voting Map in Alabama, and More
description: Exclusively from New York Times Audio, our new app.
content: The New York Times Audio app is home to journalism and storytelling, and provides news, depth and serendipity. If you haven’t already, download it here — available to Times news subscribers on iOS — and sign up for our weekly newsletter.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Liz Alderman
title: Wheat prices seesaw after Russia pulls out of the Black Sea grain deal.
description: Wheat futures rose more than 4 percent, raising fears of an increase in global food inflation.
content: The risk of renewed volatility in global food prices emerged Monday after President Vladimir V. Putin pulled Russia out of the Black Sea grain deal, rattling wheat markets and exposing vulnerable countries in Africa and the global south in particular to the prospect of a new round of food insecurity.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Colbi Edmonds
title: Iowa Judge Temporarily Suspends New Abortion Ban
description: Judge Joseph Seidlin put a hold on the law, which prohibits abortion after six weeks of pregnancy, days after the governor signed it.
content: On Friday, Iowa’s Republican governor signed a strict new abortion ban into law. And for three days, most abortions in Iowa were illegal past six weeks of pregnancy. Until Monday afternoon, when a district judge put the ban on hold.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg, Ivan Nechepurenko, Liz Alderman and Farnaz Fassihi
title: Russia Stops Ukraine Grain Deal, Shaking World Food Markets
description: Moscow, which has repeatedly complained that the U.N.-brokered agreement is one-sided in Ukraine’s favor, said it could return to the deal if its demands were met.
content: Russia said on Monday it was withdrawing from a wartime agreement to allow grain exports from Ukraine through the Black Sea until its demands to loosen sanctions on its own agricultural exports were met, upending a deal that has helped stabilize global food prices and alleviate shortages in parts of Africa and the Middle East.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Mpoke Bigg
title: What We Know About the Attack on the Crimean Bridge
description: Monday’s strike was the second in less than a year to target the Kerch Strait Bridge, which holds strategic and symbolic importance for Russia.
content: For the second time in less than a year, explosives have damaged the bridge that links Russia and Crimea, the southern Ukrainian peninsula that Moscow illegally annexed in 2014. The 12-mile-long bridge, which includes a road and rail line running side by side, is a heavily guarded piece of infrastructure that holds major importance for Russia.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neal E. Boudette
title: Electric Vehicle Prices Fall as Automakers Raise Production
description: Ford, Tesla and other automakers are having to lower prices to lure buyers as the supply of battery-powered models begins to exceed demand.
content: After struggling to find enough batteries and other parts for the past couple of years, automakers are finally beginning to churn out large numbers of electric cars and trucks. More than 30 new models will arrive in showrooms this year.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Mike Hale
title: ‘Justified: City Primeval’ Review: Raylan Redux
description: Timothy Olyphant returns in a sequel to the Kentucky crime drama “Justified,” and he’s still the coolest lawman in town, even if the town is now Detroit.
content: Eight years after he walked — gingerly, warily, every joint bent at some odd angle — into the sunset on “Justified,” Timothy Olyphant returns on Tuesday in “Justified: City Primeval,” FX’s one-off, eight-episode sequel to its hit hillbilly noir. “Justified” was one of the most entertaining television shows of the last few decades largely because of Olyphant’s cagey, obliquely sexy portrayal of Deputy U.S. Marshal Raylan Givens, a fantasy of a frontier lawman, simmering but sensitive, equally quick with a gun or a pithy comeback.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Matthew Cullen
title: A Bridge Explosion Rocked Russia
description: Also, Biden invited Netanyahu to the U.S. Here’s the latest at the end of Monday.
content: A vital bridge linking the occupied Crimean Peninsula to mainland Russia was attacked early this morning, killing two people and forcing its temporary closure.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael Crowley
title: Russia’s Embassy in Washington is enmeshed in a different kind of war.
description: WASHINGTON — On a warm June night, Benjamin Wittes was seated at a card table across the street from the Russian Embassy in Washington, kicking off his light show.
content: WASHINGTON — On a warm June night, Benjamin Wittes was seated at a card table across the street from the Russian Embassy in Washington, kicking off his light show.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The New York Times
title: Observa aves con The New York Times
description: Los cambios en las poblaciones de aves pueden ser señal de un clima cambiante. Este verano, ayuda a los científicos a conocer las aves de tu zona.
content: Nuestra comprensión de las aves se ha visto determinada en gran medida por el trabajo de la gente común y corriente. Después de todo, cualquiera puede salir a la calle y prestar atención a un mundo indómito que revolotea por encima de nosotros.
source.name: The New York Times

title: Quotation of the Day: After 75 Years, Health Service in U.K. Teeters
description: Quotation of the Day for Monday, July 17, 2023.
content: “The N.H.S. became the nation’s religion. But it’s actually a National Sickness Service.”
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amanda Holpuch
title: Mystery Object Is Found on Remote Beach in Western Australia
description: The authorities said the cylindrical object, which was found about 155 miles north of Perth, did not pose a risk to the public, but they have yet to identify it.
content: A remote beach in a part of Western Australia known for its rock lobsters and wildflowers has become home to a hulking metallic mystery object and the police officers guarding it.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Angela Serratore
title: $3 Million Homes in California
description: A three-bedroom retreat in Sebastopol, a midcentury-modern home in Laguna Niguel and a 1965 house in Sonoma.
content: This house sits on a large piece of land, surrounded by mature trees, but is just 10 minutes from the city center and about five minutes from the smaller communities of Freestone and Occidental. Wine bars, a bakery, a breakfast spot with a train theme, a Whole Foods Market and a Safeway grocery store are all nearby.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michael D. Shear and Patrick Kingsley
title: Biden Invites Netanyahu to U.S., Easing Tensions
description: The invitation to the Israeli prime minister came on the eve of a visit to the White House by Isaac Herzog, the Israeli president.
content: President Biden on Monday invited Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu of Israel to a meeting in the United States for the first time since Mr. Netanyahu re-entered office in December, easing months of tensions about the direction of Israel’s government.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Remy Tumin
title: Sinking Tugboat Spills Thousands of Gallons of Diesel in an Alabama River
description: The tugboat spilled more than 3,000 gallons of fuel into the Tennessee River in Florence, Ala., over the weekend, forcing the closure of a beach. Officials said there was no threat to drinking water.
content: A tugboat released thousands of gallons of diesel fuel as it sank into the Tennessee River in northwestern Alabama over the weekend, prompting a multiagency response from state and local officials and the closing of a local beach.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Mullin, Brooks Barnes and Nicole Sperling
title: Labor Day Looms as Crisis Point in Hollywood Stalemate
description: Ongoing strikes could disrupt the entertainment industry in fundamental ways, putting the 2024 box office and the fall broadcast lineup in jeopardy.
content: In May, when 11,500 movie and television writers went on strike, Hollywood companies like Netflix, NBCUniversal and Disney reacted with what amounted to a shrug. The walkout wasn’t great, but executives had expected it for months. They could ride it out.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Benjamin Weiser and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Federal Prosecutor Urges Takeover of Rikers Island
description: The statement from Damian Williams was a major shift and could help persuade a judge to strip Mayor Eric Adams of his power over the troubled jails complex.
content: Manhattan’s top federal prosecutor is calling for an outside authority to take control of New York City’s troubled jails, a major shift that could help persuade a judge to strip Mayor Eric Adams of his power over Rikers Island.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By The Learning Network
title: Word of the Day: glyph
description: This word has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?
content: The word glyph has appeared in six articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on Sept. 13 in “Unearthing a Maya Civilization That ‘Punched Above Its Weight’” by Franz Lidz:
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Dani Blum
title: The Risks of Taking Drugs Like Ozempic When You’re Over 65
description: Medications that cause drastic weight loss raise specific concerns for older adults.
content: There are few constants within the world of weight loss, but one concept holds up: No matter how you lose weight — through restrictive eating, bariatric surgery or the new, buzzy class of injectable medications like Ozempic and Wegovy — you’re also probably shedding muscle.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Florence Fabricant
title: Skip the Reservation With Carbone’s Jarred Vodka Sauce
description: Try the sauce from Major Food Group as well as tomato alla vodka cannellini beans from Heyday Canning, sip a lightly fizzy refreshment from Tepache Sazón, and more food news.
content: When Carbone, the high-profile wiseguys restaurant from Major Food Group, introduced its jarred pasta sauces in 2021, missing from the lineup was the restaurant’s signature Alla Vodka. Now it is finally swaggering onto supermarket shelves and online. Eric Skae, the chief executive of Carbone Fine Foods, said the goal was to replicate the restaurant experience, and that took a long time at the stove. For freshness, they wound up omitting the usual cream from the tomato and Calabrian chile mixture. Instructions on the label have you add it at home. Vodka sauce, pink, spicy, packing some heat but rarely tasting of vodka, may have originated in New York or in Italy decades ago; its popularity is undimmed. So much so that earlier this year, Heinz in England introduced its version of vodka sauce in collaboration with Absolut, the vodka company with its name on the label. In the United States, jarred vodka sauces are ubiquitous on supermarket shelves. For a new perspective, there’s now tomato alla vodka cannellini beans from Heyday Canning, a new company with a line of seasoned canned beans to serve as is or to add wherever your imagination takes you. And here, too, they’ve skipped the cream to make it vegan; coconut milk is the stand-in. The luscious cannellini in vodka sauce is excellent tossed with the requisite penne or rigatoni. Also in Heyday’s line are enchilada black beans, apricot-glazed baked beans, coconut curry chickpeas, harissa lemon chickpeas, and kimchi sesame navy beans.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Amelia Nierenberg
title: Your Tuesday Briefing: China Engages as Its Economy Sputters
description: Also, an attack on a bridge between Russia and Crimea.
content: China’s economy slowed this spring, according to official numbers released yesterday, dashing hopes of a speedy post-pandemic recovery. Analysts said growth was hampered by high levels of debt, a real estate crisis, weak exports and ebbing foreign investment.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Michelle Cottle
title: It’s Getting Really Awkward for Speaker Kevin McCarthy
description: Swing voters aren’t all that keen on posturing, do-nothing Congresses.
content: Some days, Speaker Kevin McCarthy must look out over his House conference in awe and think: Are you maniacs trying to lose us the majority?
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Isabel Kershner and Patrick Kingsley
title: What’s Next for Israel’s Judicial Overhaul?
description: Israeli lawmakers are advancing parts of a contentious plan by the right-wing government to reduce the power of the Supreme Court. A final vote is expected by early next week.
content: Israeli lawmakers are this week advancing parts of a contentious plan by the right-wing government led by Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu to overhaul the country’s judiciary.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Patricia Mazzei
title: Lionel Messi Chose Miami, and Miami Loves Him for It
description: Soccer-crazy South Florida has welcomed the world’s greatest player — now the region’s best-known celebrity — with murals, marketing and milanesas.
content: Miami’s Messi madness — over the arrival of the soccer superstar Lionel Messi, one of the most famous humans on the planet — reached a fever pitch last week when he was spotted at a Publix grocery store near Fort Lauderdale, buying Lucky Charms and Froot Loops.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Adam Liptak
title: Trump’s Judges: More Religious Ties and More N.R.A. Memberships
description: A new study also found that judges appointed by the former president were more likely to vote for claims of religious freedom — unless they came from Muslims.
content: When Donald J. Trump was running for president in 2016, he vowed to appoint Supreme Court justices who would vote to overturn Roe v. Wade. Three justices and six years later, he made good on that promise.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Robinson Meyer
title: America Can’t Build a Green Economy Without China
description: With few exceptions, you either let yourself learn from your competitors, or you fail to compete with them at all.
content: Roughly a century ago, when Henry Ford revolutionized modern car production, engineers from France, Japan, Germany and the Soviet Union flocked to Detroit to learn how to copy his miraculous methods. Ford’s River Rouge plant, then the world’s largest factory, ultimately inspired facilities by Renault, Volkswagen, Toyota and the Russian automaker Gaz. It also gave rise to the nightmarish wartime economies of World War II, when tanks, planes and toxic chemicals rolled off assembly lines worldwide.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Melissa Clark
title: Paneer Chile Dry is Spicy and Sticky, Crisp and Melting
description: And if your basil plant is going bananas, there’s punchy, speedy pad krapow gai (Thai basil chicken) and basil butter pasta.
content: In college, when I was working as a coat checker in a fancy New York restaurant, I once asked the chef what his favorite food was.
source.name: The New York Times

title: The Best Movies on Netflix Right Now
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Neil Vigdor
title: Who Might Make the Cut for the G.O.P.’s First Presidential Debate?
description: Some candidates still have a ways to go to meet the criteria for getting on the debate stage.
content: Some candidates still have a ways to go to meet the criteria for getting on the debate stage.
source.name: The New York Times

title: An Art-Filled Swiss Journey
source.name: The New York Times

title: Our Best Broccoli Recipes
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters
title: Edward Caban Named New York’s First Latino Police Commissioner
description: Edward Caban previously served as first deputy commissioner and as acting police commissioner following the resignation of Keechant Sewell, the first woman to serve in the role.
content: Edward Caban previously served as first deputy commissioner and as acting police commissioner following the resignation of Keechant Sewell, the first woman to serve in the role.
source.name: The New York Times

author: By Reuters and Storyful
title: Wildfire Smoke Covers Parts of the United States and Canada
description: Smoke from raging wildfires in the western part of Canada have begun covering parts of the United States once again, such as in the Badlands National Park area of South Dakota.
content: Smoke from raging wildfires in the western part of Canada have begun covering parts of the United States once again, such as in the Badlands National Park area of South Dakota.
source.name: The New York Times
